channel.title: How to import Auxy drum samples from Auxy to Logic pro x
channel.description: As the title says i would like to know what can i do to import Auxy drum samples from Auxy to Logic Pro X. I know that i can render every instrument as a track and put one drum sample on every drum instrument. But that would just take too much time. Do you guys know of a way to do this that is faster?

item.title: How to import Auxy drum samples from Auxy to Logic pro x
item.dc:creator: Zeph
item.description:
I don‚Äôt know if anyone has mentioned it, but you can fill up a drum kit, and program the samples seperated so they don‚Äôt overlap. Export uncompressed audio and share with airdrop. Slice the audio file and bounce the samples to new wav files.

Read full topic

item.source: How to import Auxy drum samples from Auxy to Logic pro x

item.title: How to import Auxy drum samples from Auxy to Logic pro x
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
Thanks ICS for pointing me towards this thread.

https://blackoctopus-sound.com/ is where you can find most of the licensed sound currently included in Auxy. In addition, Crate Diggers and Cutting Edge Percussion are licensed from https://originsound.co.uk/. As for the default Auxy samples, you‚Äôd need to do some work to export samples individually in order to achieve the desired result, but as opposed to 3000 samples (Leviathan 2) there‚Äôs only around 120 native to Auxy.

Also, according to Lenberg, there may be more robust exporting features coming soon for Auxy, and hopefully one of these is individual sample exports from drum kits. This will make a huge step in helping towards importing Auxy samples into Logic, as when they are exported individually it allows for better EQing of the samples.

Read full topic

item.description:
i dont see why they wouldn‚Äôt be legal. I can still upload my tracks with the old auxy sounds that I dont have anymore and exporting to other DAW‚Äôs is a built in feature of the app too, so i dont see why that would be illegal too.

As long as you‚Äôre not selling the individual sounds as your own you should be fine

item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
I would connect your iOS device to your Mac and just record everything directly via IDAM.

This is more-or-less how I use Auxy 99% of the time.

Read full topic
item.source: How to import Auxy drum samples from Auxy to Logic pro x

item.title: How to import Auxy drum samples from Auxy to Logic pro x
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
You‚Äôre in for a real long haul. You could export individual hits, cut them up and assign to whatever sampler Logic uses (ES24?) - this is going to be incredibly time consuming.

Your best bet would be to just do the work you want in Auxy and dump stems to Logic. From there you could do any layering / post processing you want/need.

For what it‚Äôs worth, if there‚Äôs a specific sample pack you really like it might be worthwhile to just get it from the source - a healthy chunk of the samples in Auxy are sourced from third party sample packs you can purchase. @TheRealJFalc knows a bit more about it and has linked some of those exact packs here

Read full topic
item.source: How to import Auxy drum samples from Auxy to Logic pro x
